name: 1618_B. Missing Bigram
description:
Polycarp has come up with a new game to play with you. He calls it "A missing bigram".

A bigram of a word is a sequence of two adjacent letters in it.

For example, word "abbaaba" contains bigrams "ab", "bb", "ba", "aa", "ab" and "ba".

The game goes as follows. First, Polycarp comes up with a word, consisting only of lowercase letters 'a' and 'b'. Then, he writes down all its bigrams on a whiteboard in the same order as they appear in the word. After that, he wipes one of them off the whiteboard.

Finally, Polycarp invites you to guess what the word that he has come up with was.

Your goal is to find any word such that it's possible to write down all its bigrams and remove one of them, so that the resulting sequence of bigrams is the same as the one Polycarp ended up with.

The tests are generated in such a way that the answer exists. If there are multiple answers, you can print any of them.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 2000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains a single integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 100) — the length of the word Polycarp has come up with.

The second line of each testcase contains n-2 bigrams of that word, separated by a single space. Each bigram consists of two letters, each of them is either 'a' or 'b'.

Additional constraint on the input: there exists at least one string such that it is possible to write down all its bigrams, except one, so that the resulting sequence is the same as the sequence in the input. In other words, the answer exists.

Output

For each testcase print a word, consisting of n letters, each of them should be either 'a' or 'b'. It should be possible to write down all its bigrams and remove one of them, so that the resulting sequence of bigrams is the same as the one Polycarp ended up with.

The tests are generated in such a way that the answer exists. If there are multiple answers, you can print any of them. 

Example

Input


4
7
ab bb ba aa ba
7
ab ba aa ab ba
3
aa
5
bb ab bb


Output


abbaaba
abaabaa
baa
bbabb

Note

The first two testcases from the example are produced from the word "abbaaba". As listed in the statement, it contains bigrams "ab", "bb", "ba", "aa", "ab" and "ba".

In the first testcase, the 5-th bigram is removed. 

In the second testcase, the 2-nd bigram is removed. However, that sequence could also have been produced from the word "abaabaa". It contains bigrams "ab", "ba", "aa", "ab", "ba" and "aa". The missing bigram is the 6-th one.

In the third testcase, all of "baa", "aab" and "aaa" are valid answers.

4
7
ab bb ba aa ba
7
ab ba aa ab ba
3
aa
5
bb ab bb

prompt:
Polycarp has come up with a new game to play with you. He calls it "A missing bigram".

A bigram of a word is a sequence of two adjacent letters in it.

For example, word "abbaaba" contains bigrams "ab", "bb", "ba", "aa", "ab" and "ba".

The game goes as follows. First, Polycarp comes up with a word, consisting only of lowercase letters 'a' and 'b'. Then, he writes down all its bigrams on a whiteboard in the same order as they appear in the word. After that, he wipes one of them off the whiteboard.

Finally, Polycarp invites you to guess what the word that he has come up with was.

Your goal is to find any word such that it's possible to write down all its bigrams and remove one of them, so that the resulting sequence of bigrams is the same as the one Polycarp ended up with.

The tests are generated in such a way that the answer exists. If there are multiple answers, you can print any of them. Make sure to consider all possible ways the bigrams can form the original word.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 2000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains a single integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 100) — the length of the word Polycarp has come up with.

The second line of each testcase contains n-2 bigrams of that word, separated by a single space. Each bigram consists of two letters, each of them is either 'a' or 'b'.

Additional constraint on the input: there exists at least one string such that it is possible to write down all its bigrams, except one, so that the resulting sequence is the same as the sequence in the input. In other words, the answer exists.

Output

For each testcase print a word, consisting of n letters, each of them should be either 'a' or 'b'. It should be possible to write down all its bigrams and remove one of them, so that the resulting sequence of bigrams is the same as the one Polycarp ended up with.

The tests are generated in such a way that the answer exists. If there are multiple answers, you can print any of them. 

Example

Input


4
7
ab bb ba aa ba
7
ab ba aa ab ba
3
aa
5
bb ab bb


Output


abbaaba
abaabaa
baa
bbabb

Note

The first two testcases from the example are produced from the word "abbaaba". As listed in the statement, it contains bigrams "ab", "bb", "ba", "aa", "ab" and "ba".

In the first testcase, the 5-th bigram is removed. 

In the second testcase, the 2-nd bigram is removed. However, that sequence could also have been produced from the word "abaabaa". It contains bigrams "ab", "ba", "aa", "ab", "ba" and "aa". The missing bigram is the 6-th one.

In the third testcase, all of "baa", "aab" and "aaa" are valid answers.
repair_prompt:
Polycarp has come up with a new game to play with you. He calls it "A missing bigram".

A bigram of a word is a sequence of two adjacent letters in it.

For example, word "abbaaba" contains bigrams "ab", "bb", "ba", "aa", "ab" and "ba".

The game goes as follows. First, Polycarp comes up with a word, consisting only of lowercase letters 'a' and 'b'. Then, he writes down all its bigrams on a whiteboard in the same order as they appear in the word. After that, he wipes one of them off the whiteboard.

Finally, Polycarp invites you to guess what the word that he has come up with was.

Your goal is to find any word such that it's possible to write down all its bigrams and remove one of them, so that the resulting sequence of bigrams is the same as the one Polycarp ended up with.

The tests are generated in such a way that the answer exists. If there are multiple answers, you can print any of them. Make sure to consider all possible ways the bigrams can form the original word.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 2000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains a single integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 100) — the length of the word Polycarp has come up with.

The second line of each testcase contains n-2 bigrams of that word, separated by a single space. Each bigram consists of two letters, each of them is either 'a' or 'b'.

Additional constraint on the input: there exists at least one string such that it is possible to write down all its bigrams, except one, so that the resulting sequence is the same as the sequence in the input. In other words, the answer exists.

Output

For each testcase print a word, consisting of n letters, each of them should be either 'a' or 'b'. It should be possible to write down all its bigrams and remove one of them, so that the resulting sequence of bigrams is the same as the one Polycarp ended up with.

The tests are generated in such a way that the answer exists. If there are multiple answers, you can print any of them. 

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4
7
ab bb ba aa ba
7
ab ba aa ab ba
3
aa
5
bb ab bb


Output


abbaaba
abaabaa
baa
bbabb

Note

The first two testcases from the example are produced from the word "abbaaba". As listed in the statement, it contains bigrams "ab", "bb", "ba", "aa", "ab" and "ba".

In the first testcase, the 5-th bigram is removed. 

In the second testcase, the 2-nd bigram is removed. However, that sequence could also have been produced from the word "abaabaa". It contains bigrams "ab", "ba", "aa", "ab", "ba" and "aa". The missing bigram is the 6-th one.

In the third testcase, all of "baa", "aab" and "aaa" are valid answers.

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def reconstruct_word(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[str]:
    """Reconstructs the original word from given bigrams for each test case.

    Args:
        t (int): The number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): A list containing lists of bigrams for each test case.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of reconstructed words for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    for bigrams in test_cases:
        # Start with the first character of the first bigram
        word = bigrams[0][0]
        # Append the first character of each subsequent bigram
        for bigram in bigrams:
            word += bigram[1]
        results.append(word)
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        bigrams = input().split()
        test_cases.append(bigrams)
    
    results = reconstruct_word(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List

def reconstruct_word(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Reconstructs the original word from the given sequence of bigrams.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n (int): The length of the original word.
            - bigrams (List[str]): A list of bigrams representing the word.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of reconstructed words for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, bigrams in test_cases:
        # Initialize the reconstructed word with the first character of the first bigram
        reconstructed_word = bigrams[0][0]
        
        # Iterate through the bigrams and construct the word
        for bigram in bigrams:
            # Append the second character of the current bigram
            reconstructed_word += bigram[1]
        
        # If the reconstructed word is longer than expected, trim it
        if len(reconstructed_word) > n:
            reconstructed_word = reconstructed_word[:n]
        
        results.append(reconstructed_word)
    
    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":

        test_cases.append((n, bigrams))
    
    results = reconstruct_word(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

from typing import List, Tuple

def reconstruct_word(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Reconstructs words from a list of bigrams for each test case.

    Args:
        t (int): The number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[str]]]): A list of tuples where each tuple contains
            an integer n and a list of n-2 bigrams.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of reconstructed words for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, bigrams in test_cases:
        # Start with the first character of the first bigram
        word = bigrams[0][0]
        
        # Iterate through each bigram and add the second character
        for bigram in bigrams:
            word += bigram[1]
        
        # If the word length is less than n, it means a bigram was missing
        # Add the second character of the last bigram to complete the word
        if len(word) < n:
            word += bigrams[-1][1]
        
        results.append(word)
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to read input, process test cases, and print results."""
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())
    
    # Collect all test cases
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        bigrams = input().split()
        test_cases.append((n, bigrams))
    
    # Call the function and print results
    results = reconstruct_word(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
import sys

def reconstruct_word(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Reconstructs words from given bigrams for multiple test cases.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[str]]]): A list of tuples where each tuple contains
            the number of bigrams and a list of bigrams.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of reconstructed words for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    for n, bigrams in test_cases:
        # Start with the first bigram
        word = bigrams[0]
        
        # Iterate over the remaining bigrams
        for i in range(1, n - 1):
            # If the last character of the current word matches the first character of the next bigram
            if word[-1] == bigrams[i][0]:
                # Append only the second character of the bigram
                word += bigrams[i][1]
            else:
                # If they don't match, append the entire bigram
                word += bigrams[i]
        
        # Append the last character of the last bigram
        word += bigrams[-1][1]
        
        results.append(word)
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to read input, process test cases, and print results."""
    input_data = sys.stdin.read().strip().split('\n')
    t = int(input_data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input_data[index])
        bigrams = input_data[index + 1].split()
        test_cases.append((n, bigrams))
        index += 2
    
    results = reconstruct_word(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List

def reconstruct_word(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[str]:
    """Reconstructs the original word from given bigrams for multiple test cases.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): List of test cases, each containing a list of bigrams.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of reconstructed words for each test case.
    """
    reconstructed_words = []

    for bigrams in test_cases:
        # Start with the first bigram
        word = bigrams[0]
        
        # Iterate through the bigrams and construct the word
        for i in range(1, len(bigrams)):
            # Append the second character of the current bigram if it doesn't match the last character of the word
            if word[-1] != bigrams[i][0]:
                word += bigrams[i][0]
            # Always append the second character of the bigram
            word += bigrams[i][1]
        
        # Append the reconstructed word to the results
        reconstructed_words.append(word)

    return reconstructed_words

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""

    test_cases = []

        n = int(input())  # Length of the word (not used directly)
        bigrams = input().split()
        test_cases.append(bigrams)

    # Call the function and print results
    results = reconstruct_word(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List
import sys

def reconstruct_word(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Reconstructs the original word from given bigrams for each test case.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of tuples where each tuple contains:
            - n (int): The length of the word to be reconstructed.
            - bigrams (List[str]): A list of bigrams.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of reconstructed words for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, bigrams in test_cases:
        # Start with the first bigram
        word = bigrams[0]
        
        # Iterate over the remaining bigrams
        for i in range(1, len(bigrams)):
            # Append the second character of the current bigram
            word += bigrams[i][1]
        
        # If the word length is less than n, append the last character of the last bigram
        if len(word) < n:
            word += bigrams[-1][1]
        
        results.append(word)
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    input_data = sys.stdin.read().strip().split('\n')
    t = int(input_data[0])
    test_cases = []
    
    for i in range(1, len(input_data), 2):
        n = int(input_data[i])
        bigrams = input_data[i + 1].split()
        test_cases.append((n, bigrams))
    
    results = reconstruct_word(t, test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 2000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains a single integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 100) — the length of the word Polycarp has come up with.

The second line of each testcase contains n-2 bigrams of that word, separated by a single space. Each bigram consists of two letters, each of them is either 'a' or 'b'.

Additional constraint on the input: there exists at least one string such that it is possible to write down all its bigrams, except one, so that the resulting sequence is the same as the sequence in the input. In other words, the answer exists.

Output

For each testcase print a word, consisting of n letters, each of them should be either 'a' or 'b'. It should be possible to write down all its bigrams and remove one of them, so that the resulting sequence of bigrams is the same as the one Polycarp ended up with.

The tests are generated in such a way that the answer exists. If there are multiple answers, you can print any of them. 

Example

Input


4
7
ab bb ba aa ba
7
ab ba aa ab ba
3
aa
5
bb ab bb


Output


abbaaba
abaabaa
baa
bbabb

Note

The first two testcases from the example are produced from the word "abbaaba". As listed in the statement, it contains bigrams "ab", "bb", "ba", "aa", "ab" and "ba".

In the first testcase, the 5-th bigram is removed. 

In the second testcase, the 2-nd bigram is removed. However, that sequence could also have been produced from the word "abaabaa". It contains bigrams "ab", "ba", "aa", "ab", "ba" and "aa". The missing bigram is the 6-th one.

In the third testcase, all of "baa", "aab" and "aaa" are valid answers.
